@foreveryang321 Thank for your info. 
At the other extreme, we would like to know if the remote method invocation functionality provided by Dubbo requires extra port to be open?
With JAVA RMI protocol, we all know that the connection requires EXTRA port to be open. This port is randomly selected from the available ports. 
And clearly, we have no control over the selected port. This leads to potential issue with firewall policy on running machine.

Our question is:
1. Does Dubbo take control over the extra port assignment with RMI protocol?
2. If it is not, we will start to look to the other protocols, such as default Dubbo protocol or http. And for these protocols, does Dubbo open EXTRA port also to provide the remote method invocation functionality?

One of the solution that we can think of is to write down the stream of objects to a local file. Then the interface returns a FileInputStream of that local file.

However, this solution really kills the beauty of java.util.stream.

We bet that the Dubbo community, with years of experience working with remote method invocation, would have a more efficient and adequate solution for this issue.

        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.dubbo</groupId>
            <artifactId>dubbo</artifactId>
            <version>${dubbo.version}</version>
            <exclusions>
                <exclusion>
                    <groupId>org.springframework</groupId>
                    <artifactId>spring-context</artifactId>
                </exclusion>
                <exclusion>
                    <groupId>log4j</groupId>

                </exclusion>
